meta_home_description: Developing Reciprocal Intelligence: an offline-first, community-governed design standard for Indigenous territories.
meta_whitepaper_title: Qori Labs | SMS Prototype Technical Note
hero_lead: Reciprocal Intelligence: An offline-first, community-governed standard for intelligent systems in Indigenous territories.
hero_sub: Qori Labs is a non-commercial research initiative. We design systems that communities can own, govern, and shut down.
summary_ri_body: It is a proposed design and governance standard to ensure AI and digital systems in rural territories serve community wellbeing, not extraction. It aligns with UNDRIP and Andean values to prioritize sovereignty over scale.
prop_reciprocity: Reciprocity as Obligation: Systems must return tangible value (Ayni) to the territory.
prop_authority: Community Authority as Law: Local assemblies hold binding power over system operation.
prop_infrastructure: Offline-First Infrastructure: Systems run on community-controlled hardware, not the cloud.
framework_now_standard_body: Developing the Reciprocal Intelligence standard, including governance patterns like Community AI Councils, Boundary Cards, and the Ayni License.
framework_now_tech_body: Designing LoRa and SMS-based emergency communication systems that operate independently of internet connectivity.
framework_now_proto_body: Testing concept verification models in lab environments. No active pilots or deployments in communities.
home_status: Transparency Note: This initiative is in the conceptual research phase. No community deployments, pilots, or territorial commitments are currently active.
footer_rights: All research outputs are co-licensed under Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0 and community agreements.
ri_overview_sub: A proposed governance and technical standard for enforcing community authority over artificial intelligence and digital systems.
ri_use_communities_body: Use as a checklist for negotiation. If an outside project cannot meet these reciprocity and sovereignty standards, consent should be withheld.
ri_use_researchers_body: Use as conditions in MoUs and RFPs. Ensure funding includes budget for independent community governance and offline infrastructure.
ri_checklist_council: Operate under a legitimate Community AI Council with binding powers.
ri_checklist_fpic: Use FPIC vivo (continuous consent) for all data decisions.
ri_checklist_kill: Provide a community-held hard kill switch.
ri_checklist_reciprocity: Enforce reciprocity via Value Return Agreements.
ri_checklist_boundaries: Implement Boundary Cards in policy and code.
ri_phase1_body: Documenting Andean governance models, defining Boundary Cards, and prototyping offline infrastructure reference kits.
ri_phase2_body: Conditional on community invitation: Co-designing Councils and lab-testing modules under simulated governance reviews.
ri_phase3_body: Aspirational: If territories align, publishing open compliance tests and federated reciprocity protocols.
ri_alignment_care: CARE Principles: Collective Benefit, Authority to Control, Responsibility, Ethics.
ri_alignment_undrip: UNDRIP / ILO 169: Standards on self-determination and FPIC.
ri_alignment_unesco: UNESCO AI Ethics: Alignment with global impact assessment tools.
ri_alignment_participatory: Participatory AI: Drawing from democratic governance research (e.g., cip.org, pro-ethics.eu).
projects_intro: Conceptual designs and lab prototypes under the Reciprocal Intelligence framework. None are currently deployed.
projects_recip_description: Developing the standard: Community AI Council models, Boundary Cards, Ayni License, Reciprocity Ledger, and Policy Gatekeeper patterns.
projects_emerg_body: LoRa and SMS architectures for safety-of-life alerts in rural regions. Ensuring critical functions run on community-controlled devices with kill switches.
projects_sms_body: CLI + GSM workflow encoding FPIC enforcement and privacy safeguards. A potential module of Reciprocal Intelligence.
projects_higherself_body: Early research on encoding Andean ethical principles into federated AI. Now serves as historical input for Reciprocal Intelligence.
ethics_status_note: Qori Labs operates as a non-commercial lab. All work is currently conceptual or restricted to lab environments.
ethics_consent_body: We operate under the standard of Free, Prior, and Informed Consent (FPIC). However, we go further with "FPIC vivo"—consent must be continuous, revocable, and verifiable by the community at any moment, not just a one-time signature.
ethics_firewall_body: Qori Labs is a non-commercial research initiative. Any future licensing involving community knowledge must be co-designed with communities, governed by their institutions, and strictly protected from extractive market pressures.
ethics_intro: We translate ethical concerns into enforceable technical guarantees:
whitepaper_scope_note: Technical Note: A modular building block for offline community alerts.
contact_intro: We welcome contact from Indigenous organizations, universities, and public-interest institutions interested in the Reciprocal Intelligence standard.
contact_status_note: Note: Qori Labs is in a conceptual research phase. We are not a vendor or a startup. Reaching out does not imply an active project in your territory.
contact_notice: Commercial solicitations will not receive a response.
ri_full_standard_intro: The following article documents the Reciprocal Intelligence vision, institutional design, reciprocity stack, and phased roadmap in full detail. It is intended as a citation-ready reference for communities, researchers, and policy partners.
ri_part1_title: Part 1: Reciprocal Intelligence — Vision, Foundations, and Standard
ri_part1_intro: Part 1 sets the political and technical context, grounds the work in current practice, and defines the core RI compliance threshold.
ri_part1_section1_title: 1. The inflection point: agents, invisibility, and design power
ri_part1_section1_body:
Autonomous AI agents are rapidly becoming the default interface to economic, social, and administrative life. They:

  • broker prices, contracts, and logistics,
  • gate access to subsidies, credit, and services,
  • translate, summarize, and narrate the world on behalf of institutions and platforms.

If Andean and other Indigenous communities do not exist inside this new “intelligence layer” in their own languages, with their own institutions and boundaries encoded, they risk interface poverty:

  • treated as illegible: no data, no standard fields, no recognized authority,
  • mispriced: buyers’ agents see “risk” without context or ignore communal protections,
  • extracted from: cultural and ecological knowledge scraped into models with no consent or reciprocity,
  • governed from elsewhere: optimization routines overwrite communal calendars, water rules, and sacred limits.

This trajectory is not inevitable and not merely technical. It is a political design choice about:

  • whose values become defaults,
  • whose governance has binding force,
  • who has the recognized right to say “no”, “not like this”, or “stop”.

Reciprocal Intelligence is a proposal to make a different choice.
ri_part1_section2_body:
This framework emerges from concrete, ongoing work in Andean territories:

  • LoRa-first, offline-first communication networks for coordination and safety in highland and rural geographies.
  • Store-and-forward architectures using SMS, Bluetooth, and community radio under intermittent connectivity.
  • Community-level processes experimenting with FPIC vivo—consent as iterative, revisitable, and locally intelligible.
  • Indigenous data governance protocols aligned with the CARE Principles, UNDRIP, and Indigenous-led charters.

These pilots are limited and context-specific, yet Reciprocal Intelligence generalizes their lessons into an architecture for agent economies that:

  • treats Andean communities as constitutional actors,
  • prioritizes safety, reciprocity, and sovereignty,
  • is realistic for low-resource, offline-first conditions.
ri_part1_section3_body:
Reciprocal Intelligence (RI) is a design and governance standard for AI and agent systems in Indigenous and rural territories. A system aligned with RI must satisfy three core properties:

  • Reciprocity as obligation: every interaction involving community data, knowledge, infrastructure, or risk carries enforceable reciprocity duties defined locally (Ayni).
  • Community authority as law: legitimate institutions hold binding power to grant or withhold consent, set boundaries, audit behavior, and pause or terminate systems.
  • Community infrastructure as substrate: critical functions—policy enforcement, logs, kill switch, key services—run on community-controlled, offline-capable infrastructure.

RI stands against one-way extraction, shallow “inclusion” narratives, and infrastructures that render communities legible only as markets or datasets.
ri_part1_section4_title: 4. Foundations: reciprocity, sovereignty, and global guidance
ri_part1_section4_body:
RI operationalizes established bodies of work:

  • Indigenous reciprocity and governance: Ayni, Minka/Minga, asamblea, and ayllu are treated as sophisticated institutional designs balancing autonomy, ecology, and care.
  • Indigenous data sovereignty and AI ethics: CARE Principles, UNDRIP, UNESCO AI ethics guidance, Indigenous AI Protocols, and emerging Indigenous data governance frameworks.
  • Digital sovereignty tools: social license mechanisms for AI/data reuse and legal instruments for data sovereignty and usage control.

Reciprocal Intelligence translates these principles into concrete governance and technical requirements for the Andean, offline-first context.
ri_part1_section5_title: 5. The Community AI Council: institutional heart of RI
ri_part1_section5_body:
The Consejo de IA Comunitaria (Community AI Council) is the primary local authority for AI and agents under RI. It is not an external ethics committee; it evolves from assemblies, sectoral committees, cooperatives, spiritual authorities, and existing Indigenous protocols.

Non-negotiable mandates:

  • Exercise FPIC vivo—approve, reject, or revoke projects as consent conditions change.
  • Lead creation of Cultural Boundary Cards defining sacred, communal, shared, and public knowledge.
  • Audit systems for cultural distortion, bias, disrespect, and harm.
  • Control hardware and software kill switches to pause or exit deployments.
  • Oversee Value Return Agreements and the Reciprocity Ledger.
  • Report transparently to the asamblea and remain recallable.

Composition principles include representation (women, youth, language keepers, spiritual stewards), term limits, and clear decision rules.
ri_part1_section6_title: 6. The RI reciprocity stack: making Ayni enforceable
ri_part1_section6_body:
RI defines a minimal, enforceable stack:

  • Value Return Agreements (VRAs): contract clauses specifying value flows, timelines, penalties, and suspension conditions.
  • Reciprocity Ledger: a community-visible log (SMS, radio, noticeboard) of agreed returns and delivery status.
  • Ayni License: a community license attached to cultural, knowledge, and ecological assets that prohibits extraction and mandates reciprocity.
  • Policy Gatekeeper: a technical enforcement point that inspects requests, checks FPIC status, Boundary Cards, VRAs, and the Ayni License, and logs every decision.

Reciprocity lives in contracts, code, logs, and public memory.
ri_part1_section7_title: 7. Three-phase roadmap: disciplined, feasible, and conditional
ri_part1_section7_body:
• Phase 1 — Foundations (0–18 months): establish the Council, Boundary Cards, Data Trust, Ayni License, Reciprocal Intelligence Node (RIN), Policy Gatekeeper, kill switch, and Reciprocity Ledger.
  • Phase 2 — Accountable Local Agents (18–36 months): introduce narrow agents for negotiation, culture, and collective action under strict Council oversight.
  • Phase 3 — Federated Network (36+ months): connect RINs, publish compliance tests, and embed RI safeguards into policy—only if earlier phases deliver.

Each phase is conditional on the previous one’s success; there is no skipping ahead.
ri_part1_section8_title: 8. Reciprocal Intelligence compliance: the core standard
ri_part1_section8_body:
Any AI or agent deployment claiming RI alignment must:

  • operate under a legitimate Community AI Council or assembly with binding powers,
  • implement FPIC vivo and CARE Principles across data and model lifecycles,
  • run critical controls (policies, logs, kill switch) on community infrastructure wherever feasible,
  • provide community-held kill switches,
  • enforce reciprocity using VRAs and a public Reciprocity Ledger,
  • adopt Boundary Cards in policy and code,
  • offer transparent documentation in community languages and channels.

RI is not branding; it is a testable compliance bar.
ri_part2_intro: Phase 2 introduces narrow, reversible agents that operate strictly under the architecture and authority built in Phase 1.
ri_part2_section1_body:
Objectives:

  • Test whether agents can improve economic dignity, cultural narrative power, and collective action without eroding sovereignty.
  • Show that autonomous systems can be subordinated to Indigenous governance and reciprocity.

Non-negotiable preconditions: active Community AI Council, enforced Boundary Cards, Data Trust and Ayni License in use, functioning RIN, tested Policy Gatekeeper and kill switch, and a public Reciprocity Ledger. If these are not real, Phase 2 does not start.
ri_part2_section2_body:
• Council-governed approvals for every deployment and update.
  • Policy Gatekeeper enforcement of FPIC status, Boundary Cards, Ayni License, and VRAs.
  • Local-first execution where feasible to maximize inspectability.
  • Minimal, legible scopes explained via SMS, radio, or assemblies.
  • Reversibility with per-agent kill switches and clear rollback paths.
  • Non-substitutive roles that assist rather than replace communal processes.
ri_part2_section3_title: 3. Agent 1: Negotiation Agent for Fairer Markets
ri_part2_section3_body:
Supports small farmers to secure transparent offers and avoid predatory contracts.

  • Core functions: aggregate community-approved production data, discover offers, filter against Council rules, recommend bilingual contract summaries.
  • Governance: Council sets price floors, banned clauses, and required reciprocity contributions; VRAs encode obligations; the Policy Gatekeeper blocks violations; all negotiations are logged publicly.

This agent tests whether RI can deliver measurable economic benefit without ceding control.
ri_part2_section4_title: 4. Agent 2: Cultural Knowledge Agent for Dignified Storytelling
ri_part2_section4_body:
Helps weaving collectives, artisans, and community media narrate their own stories with accuracy and dignity.

  • Generates bilingual descriptions, exhibition texts, and educational snippets within Boundary Card limits.
  • Implements a Sacred Null response for restricted content and attaches the Ayni License to every output.
  • Council defines what is public, restricted, or off-limits; Data Trust controls training data; Policy Gatekeeper enforces no export of protected material.
  • Reciprocity mechanisms ensure royalties or agreed returns are logged when narratives are reused.
ri_part2_section5_title: 5. Agent 3: Collective Action Agent for Water and Safety
ri_part2_section5_body:
Assists water committees and community responders with irrigation scheduling, communal work coordination, and emergency alerts.

  • Drafts proposals that respect customary rules, sacred periods, and environmental cues.
  • Sends SMS/LoRa notifications for minka/minga work and safety check-ins.
  • Asamblea supremacy: outputs are proposals until ratified; Boundary Cards govern ecological data sharing; Policy Gatekeeper blocks unauthorized exports; dedicated kill switch allows immediate pause.
ri_part2_section6_title: 6. Technical architecture for Phase 2 (keeping it simple and sovereign)
ri_part2_section6_body:
• Reciprocal Intelligence Node (RIN) hosts policy engines, logs, and local agent components.
  • Policy Gatekeeper remains the mandatory path for external APIs and agent negotiations.
  • Prefer small, inspectable models; route larger models through the Gatekeeper with full logging.
  • Data minimization limits what agents can access; sensitive data stays local.
  • Versioning and audit trails document every change and approval.

Phase 2 mirrors the discipline of staged clinical testing: targeted, monitored, and reversible.
ri_part2_section7_body:
• Pre-deployment review: each agent has a short spec reviewed by the Council.
  • Community briefing: assemblies explain scope, boundaries, and complaint channels.
  • Continuous audit: stewards sample outputs and compare against Boundary Cards.
  • Feedback loops: SMS codes, in-person visits, and radio slots capture community concerns.
  • Fast-pause protocol: predefined triggers allow immediate shutdown pending investigation.
ri_part2_section8_body:
• Agents measurably improve economic, cultural, or governance indicators.
  • Harms are detected, paused, and remedied transparently.
  • Community members can explain what agents do and who controls them.
  • Institutional foundations (Council, Data Trust, RIN, Gatekeeper, Ledger) remain active.

Without these conditions, do not attempt federation.
ri_part3_title: Part 3: Phase 3 — Federated Andean Network and RI Standard
ri_part3_intro: Phase 3 federates mature Reciprocal Intelligence Nodes without abandoning sovereignty. It is unrelated to literacy “Phase 3” materials.
ri_part3_section1_body:
• Build shared power so communities negotiate, learn, and defend together inside the intelligence layer.
  • Normalize RI as the default standard for AI/agents in Indigenous and rural territories.
  • Demonstrate an alternative to platform colonialism by linking sovereign nodes, not replacing them.

Many strong locals → voluntary federation → leverage.
ri_part3_section2_title: 2. Design principles for the federated network
ri_part3_section2_body:
• Federation, not centralization; no root platform.
  • Opt-in interoperability with per-community licenses and VRAs.
  • Shared RI protections (FPIC vivo, CARE alignment, offline infra, kill switch, reciprocity, Boundary Cards).
  • Minimal exposure: only aggregated, license-compliant signals leave a community.
  • Reversibility: participation can be paused or revoked at any time.
ri_part3_section3_body:
Each RIN runs local policy, logs, and agents. Federation means exposing only Council-approved interfaces and schemas for shared signals (prices, hazards, reciprocity status).

Example: potato-growing communities coordinate minimum prices by sharing anonymized projections and jointly refusing exploitative buyers.
ri_part3_section4_title: 4. Shared reciprocity and defense: Federated Reciprocity Ledger
ri_part3_section4_body:
Local ledgers remain community-controlled, but selected entries (partner name, agreement type, compliance status) can feed a regional index.

  • Enhances transparency about which actors honor reciprocity.
  • Supports collective defense when institutions underperform.

All sharing is opt-in, governed by Councils and Data Trusts, and bound by the Ayni License.
ri_part3_section5_body:
Phase 3 allows regionally scoped agents—negotiation, safety, cultural visibility—only when participating Councils explicitly mandate them.

  • All cross-community agents must route through each local Policy Gatekeeper.
  • Any Council can pause participation unilaterally.
  • No agent may demand raw sacred or communal data.
ri_part3_section6_title: 6. Governance at the federated level: Council of Councils
ri_part3_section6_body:
A light federation body composed of delegates from each Community AI Council coordinates shared standards, mutual aid, and external advocacy.

  • Rotating, recallable representation with diversity commitments.
  • Mandate limited to coordination, mutual audits, and collective negotiation.
  • No authority to override local Boundary Cards or impose projects.
ri_part3_section7_title: 7. Institutionalizing Reciprocal Intelligence as a standard
ri_part3_section7_body:
• Municipal and regional ordinances require RI safeguards before AI deployments proceed.
  • National AI strategies integrate RI as a protective regime for Indigenous territories.
  • Donors, NGOs, and research ethics boards adopt the RI checklist in grants and approvals.
  • Technical ecosystems (open-source projects, labs, companies) treat RI compliance as a legitimacy bar.
ri_part3_section8_body:
• RI offers clarity: abstract promises become auditable requirements.
  • It reduces legal, reputational, and political risk for partners.
  • It creates trusted collaboration channels where boundaries and benefits are explicit.
  • Communities gain shared strength, learning, and defense rather than negotiating alone.
ri_part3_section9_body:
• Multiple communities run mature RINs and Phase 2 agents under RI.
  • A functioning Council of Councils coordinates without eroding sovereignty.
  • RI principles appear in policy instruments and partner requirements.
  • Economic, cultural, and governance indicators show measurable improvement.
  • Communities can cite moments where systems were stopped, contracts refused, or reciprocity enforced.

If these conditions are absent, federation should pause and foundations should be reinforced.
meta_3dprint_title: Qori Labs | 3D Ruray: Kikin Kamachiy Ayni Yuyaywan
meta_3dprint_description: 3D printing indigenous hardware Andes 2025 perovskite efficiency: 26.2% solar cells, IP65+ LoRa enclosures, 40-60% cost savings. From 98% imports to local sovereignty.
3dprint_hero_label: Plastico Ayni: Ruray kamachiy qhipa punchawman
3dprint_hero_sub: In October 2025, scientists achieved 26.2% efficiency in 3D-printed perovskite solar cells. In November 2024, Chile completed Latin America's first 3D-printed home 50% faster than traditional methods. Yet indigenous territories at 4,800m still wait 21 days for a $3 plastic enclosure while emergencies unfold. With 110.2% market growth and proven 40-60% cost savings, sovereignty isn't negotiable—it's printable.
3dprint_declaration: Rurayqa manan tecnología hapinachu. Ñawpaq runa hayñi kutichiy: ayllu amachanapaq yanapakuna ruray.
3dprint_solar_breakthrough_title: 26.2% Efficient Printable Solar: The Game Changer
3dprint_solar_breakthrough_body: <cite index="1">October 2025: TechXplore reports 26.2% efficiency in 3D-printed perovskite cells</cite>, with <cite index="3">97% retention after 1000 hours maximum power point tracking</cite>. For high-altitude indigenous territories, this means printable power generation resistant to UV index 14 and low oxygen. <cite index="4">LONGi's 34.6% tandem achievement</cite> shows the path to complete energy sovereignty by 2027.
3dprint_latam_title: Latin America Leads: From Houses to Hardware
3dprint_chile_body: <cite index="11,12,15">November 2024: Latin America's first 3D-printed home completed in Biobío</cite>. Built 50% faster, withstanding 8.8 magnitude earthquake standards. Cost savings: 40-60% over traditional construction.
3dprint_mexico_body: <cite index="18">500sqft 3D-printed homes for poverty alleviation</cite>. Proven in humid, seismic zones. Model adaptable for high-altitude refugios using local materials.
3dprint_market_body: <cite index="40">Latin America's 3D construction market explodes at 110.2% CAGR 2025-2030</cite>. Indigenous territories can capture this growth through community-controlled fabrication.
footer_hardware: Hardware designs additionally released under CERN-OHL-S for maximum sovereignty.
